abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is satisfactory,
            sustainability likely, and institutional development impacts
            substantial. Positive lessons highlight, and reinforce that
            precise, and realistic goals, clearly reflecting the
            Government's will to higher education reform,
            characterize chances for success, entrusted by government
            officials in the sustained implementation pace. Moreover,
            the sound analytical preparation, and policy consultations
            facilitated implementation, and achievement of development
            objectives, to in addition, prod readily business
            partnerships due to the specificity of project structures.
            Such partnerships also succeeded in part, because the type
            of training offered by the Higher Institutes of Technology,
            met the needs of both public and private enterprises,
            offering a common factor in technological advancement.
            Furthermore, this type of training considerably improves the
            academic standards of higher education. Nonetheless,
            negative lessons point at the weak consultation, and
            information process with stakeholders, which could have been
            improved, had prudent assessment of political risks been
            undertaken prior to reform implementation. And if the
            Government expects to maintain those educational reforms
            that succeeded, it will be crucial to invest in long-tem
            gains, rather than in seeking short-term political benefits.

5079223.trustfund:
TF029506-PHRD-HIGHER EDUCATION REFORM PROJ.,TF034039-TUNISIA - EDUCATION,TF032656-TUNISIA - HIGHER EDUCATION
            RESTRUCTURING PROJECT,TF031089-TUNISIA HIGHER EDUCATION,TF031014-TUNISIA HIGHER EDUCATION,TF032655-TUNISIA - HIGHER EDUCATION
            RESTRUCTURING PROJECT,TF034685-TUNISIA - HIGHER EDUCATION
            RESTRUC. PROJECT,TF020250-FRENCH CONSULTANTS TRUST FUND

abstracts.cdata!:
The project aims at making the higher
            education system more cost effective and responsive to the
            needs of the country.  More specifically it will: i)
            diversify the higher education system in order to improve
            the output of a trained technical and managerial labor
            force; ii) provide incentives to universities to revise
            curricula to enhance the quality of teaching and learning;
            and iii) strengthen the planning and managerial capacities
            of the higher education system. Project components include
            the creation of a new generation of Higher Institutes of
            Technology (ISET) which would be geared towards labor market
            needs.  Five ISETS would be developed in the main economic
            and industrial regions (Tunis, Nabeul, Gabes, Sfax, and
            Sousse). The ISETS would limit enrollment to 1500 - 1800
            students per ISET and use curricula with disciplines related
            to local industry and service sectors. Another component
            would create a National Program for University Improvement
            (PNRU).  This program would channel funds towards existing
            universities with the aim of increasing their internal and
            external efficiency, allowing resources to be used as an
            incentive for universities to reform their programs and
            curricula.  Reforms would include: new undergraduate study
            programs; diversification of streams to increase career
            options; and improvement of secondary teachers training
            programs.  The last component involves strengthening the
            planning and managerial capacities of the higher education system.
